instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
hello friend all good ? 
I'm with this mac that suffered contact with liquid in the UB400,UB300 components and the <SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL> mesh, where <RESISTOR>R9350</RESISTOR> was corroded, I remade the broken track and replace the <RESISTOR>R9350</RESISTOR>.
The voltages of the board are: 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> 0V ~ 5.08V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.49V ~ 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 1.50V ~ 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_X_USBC</SIGNAL> 0v
I hope that these measures will help to understand the problem! :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> 0V ~ 5.08V "
Does this mean you have 20V at the other 3 USB-C ports?
If not, I don't understand why do you post the voltage for one port only...

"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.49V ~ 0V "
The board cannot start, if <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is not steady; SMC will not work and obviously impossible to get 20V at any USB-C port.

Compare diode mode readings at LDO outputs between all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips; each one has 4 LDO outputs!
Do you get steady 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Faixa de diodo nas saídas LDO nos chips <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, UB400, UB300, <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>:
----> <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
-<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> 0.506V
-<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 0.535V
-<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 0.540V
-<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> 0.544V
----> UB400
-<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> 0.506V
-<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 0.530V
-<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 0.519V
-<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> 0.544V

----> UB300
-<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> 0.508V
-<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 0.542V
-<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 0.545V
-<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> 0.549V

---> <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
-<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> 0.509V
-<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 0.530V
-<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 0.544V
-<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> 0.548V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Something else affected by liquid on UB300/400 area.
Can be UB000/90, or a simple cap, or resistor.
These chips are also connected to CPU, so damage can be worst.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
I have replaced UB400 and nearby oxidized components, but the PPBUS is still at 100mV. could it be the <CHIP>U5000</CHIP>?  How can I identify my measurements? 
     I would really like to solve this mac, I am trying for almost a year.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: Liquid spillage, with visible oxidation on these high-density boards, is many times letal.
